questions.text: A 73-year-old woman presents to the primary care clinic for evaluation of six months of easy bruising, thinning skin, polyuria, hypertension, and central obesity with violaceous striae. The patient has no significant past medical history and takes no medications. She has been smoking one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 45 years. Temperature is 37.0ºC (98.6ºF), blood pressure is 152/91 mmHg and pulse is 90/min. Supraclavicular and dorsocervical fat pads are noted to be enlarged. Neurologic examination shows proximal muscle weakness bilaterally. The abdomen is obese with dark terminal hairs and violaceous striae. 24-hour urinary free cortisol and late-night salivary cortisol levels are significantly elevated. Computed tomography (CT) imaging of the abdomen shows a 9-mm left adrenal mass. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain shows a 7-mm pituitary mass. The patient undergoes inferior petrosal sinus sampling which does not demonstrate a central-to-peripheral adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) pituitary gradient. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient with multiple signs and symptoms of hypercortisolism has late-night salivary and 24-hour urinary free cortisol measurements that confirm the diagnosis of Cushing syndrome. The elevated serum adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) indicates ACTH-dependent Cushing syndrome. The patient is found to have a pituitary microadenoma (<10 mm), but inferior petrosal sinus sampling does not indicate that the pituitary gland is the source of ACTH. Therefore, CT imaging of the chest should be done to look for small cell lung cancer, which is the most likely ectopic source of ACTH in this patient with a significant smoking history.

Once Cushing syndrome is confirmed, plasma ACTH levels should be measured. If ACTH is low, then this indicates ACTH-independent Cushing syndrome and abdominal imaging should be performed to look for an adrenal mass. If ACTH is high then the patient has ACTH-dependent Cushing syndrome, and a brain MRI should be performed to look for a pituitary source of ACTH. If a pituitary macroadenoma(≥10 mm) is found, this is likely the source and the condition is referred to as Cushing disease. If a microadenoma (<10 mm) is found, then inferior petrosal sinus sampling should be performed. The ACTH levels in the blood from the petrosal sinus (central) are compared to the levels in the peripheral vein. A significant central-to-peripheral ACTH pituitary gradient (often a ratio greater than 2 or 3 at baseline, and greater than 3 after CRH stimulation) indicates a central source of ACTH (i.e. the pituitary gland). If there is no significant gradient, it suggests that ACTH production is coming from somewhere other than the pituitary, indicating an ectopic source. The next step given the low central-to-peripheral ACTH pituitary gradient is to perform chest imaging to look for a lung malignancy. Ectopic ACTH production from small cell lung cancer is typically treated with tumor resection.

Management of Cushing syndrome depends on the underlying cause of the condition. Management of Cushing disease from a pituitary adenoma should include surgical consultation to determine if tumor resection with transsphenoidal adenomectomy is appropriate. This is usually followed by hormone replacement therapy with growth hormone and glucocorticoids. Alternatively, if surgery is not appropriate, radiotherapy can be considered. Other treatment options include medical therapy with adrenal steroidogenesis inhibitors, like ketoconazole and metyrapone, or somatostatin receptor ligands, like pasireotide.

Bilateral adrenalectomy can be used to definitively treat adrenal hyperplasia, and unilateral adrenalectomy can definitively treat adrenal adenomas. The adrenal enzyme inhibitors (metyrapone or ketoconazole) can be given to reduce cortisol secretion in order to improve patients’ physical condition before surgery.
 

Option Analysis

✅ CT imaging of the chest:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Transsphenoidal adenomectomy:
Incorrect: This is a treatment option for patients with Cushing disease (glucocorticoid excess due to a pituitary mass). Though this patient has a microadenoma, the negative findings from petrosal sinus sampling indicate an ectopic source of ACTH and not a pituitary source.  
❌ Pituitary radiotherapy:
Incorrect: This is a treatment option for patients with Cushing disease (glucocorticoid excess due to a pituitary mass). Although this patient has a microadenoma, the petrosal sinus sampling indicates that an ectopic source of ACTH is the cause, not a pituitary source.  
❌ Adrenal mass resection:
Incorrect: This is a treatment option for patients with Cushing syndrome due to a hormonally active adrenal mass (which would cause low serum ACTH). This patient has ACTH-dependent Cushing syndrome, so the adrenal finding on imaging is likely an incidentaloma and not related to this patient’s presentation.  
❌ Ketoconazole and metyrapone:
Incorrect: These medications are adrenal steroidogenesis inhibitors and can be used as medical therapy to treat Cushing syndrome due to adrenal or pituitary overproduction. This patient likely has an ectopic ACTH source, and imaging should be done first to determine the etiology.

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with the abrupt onset of severe headache, palpitations, and diaphoresis. She reports similar episodes over the past two months. Past medical history includes uncontrolled hypertension despite adherence to a three-medication antihypertensive regimen, including a diuretic, calcium channel blocker, and ACE inhibitor. The patient’s sister was diagnosed with a paraganglioma two years ago. Temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), blood pressure is 210/125 mmHg, pulse is 130/min, respiratory rate is 22/min, and O<sub>2</sub> saturation is 97% on room air. Physical examination reveals an anxious-appearing woman. Her skin is cool and clammy. Cardiac exam reveals tachycardia without murmurs. Neurologic examination shows no focal abnormalities. Laboratory results are significant for a creatinine of 2.2 mg/dL. An ECG is significant for sinus tachycardia. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: MRI of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
This patient presenting with an abrupt and severe headache, palpitations, diaphoresis, severe hypertension, elevated creatinine and a history of uncontrolled hypertension and a familial history of paraganglioma, likely has a pheochromocytoma presenting as a hypertensive emergency. An alpha-adrenergic receptor blocker like intravenous phentolamine can be used as initial treatment. It decreases blood pressure by counteracting the vasoconstrictive effects of the catecholamines secreted by the pheochromocytoma.

Pheochromocytomas are catecholamine-secreting tumors that can cause paroxysmal hypertension and precipitate hypertensive emergencies. The immediate goal of treatment is to control blood pressure and reduce the risk of serious complications, such as stroke, myocardial infarction, and aortic dissection. An alpha-adrenergic receptor blocker such as phentolamine can be used to lower blood pressure quickly in a hypertensive emergency caused by a pheochromocytoma. Alpha-blockade must be initiated before beta-blockade to prevent a paradoxical hypertensive crisis from unopposed alpha stimulation. Nitroprusside which is a vasodilator can also be used, as well as nicardipine.

Following the acute management of hypertension, the next step in management is to confirm the diagnosis with biochemical testing, typically with a plasma-free metanephrines test or a 24-hour urine collection for catecholamines, metanephrines, and creatinine. Once the diagnosis of pheochromocytoma is confirmed, definitive treatment is surgical removal of the tumor. Before surgery can be performed, the patient must undergo a period of preoperative alpha-blockade (and then possibly beta-blockade) to prevent intraoperative hypertensive crises.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Intravenous phentolamine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Intravenous labetalol:
Incorrect: Labetalol is a combined alpha- and beta-blocker used in the management of hypertensive emergencies. However, in patients with suspected pheochromocytomas, alpha-blockade must be established before beta-blockade. Starting a beta-blocker before an alpha-blocker can lead to worsened hypertension due to unopposed alpha-adrenergic stimulation.  
❌ Oral ramipril:
Incorrect: ACE inhibitors like ramipril are often used for chronic management of hypertension, but they are not appropriate for the management of hypertensive emergencies.  
❌ MRI of the abdomen and pelvis:
Incorrect: An MRI of the abdomen and pelvis can assist in tumor localization once the diagnosis of pheochromocytoma has been biochemically confirmed. It is not the first step in management for a patient with a hypertensive emergency.  
❌ CT scan of the head:
Incorrect: CT scan of the head would be useful for evaluating the cause of a headache if there was suspicion of CNS pathology. This patient has no focal neurologic findings and other symptoms and signs suggestive of a pheochromocytoma.

questions.text: A 47-year-old man presents to the emergency room for evaluation of 3 days of diffuse abdominal pain. He has been having intermittent episodes of palpitations and headaches over the past few months, which he attributes to work-related stress. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and a 15-year smoking history. Current medications include hydrochlorothiazide, lisinopril, and amlodipine. On physical examination, his temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 165/95 mmHg, pulse is 90/min, and respiratory rate is 16/min. His abdomen is soft, non-tender, and non-distended. A computed tomography (CT) scan of the abdomen shows a 3 cm mass overlying the right adrenal gland, suggestive of an adrenal adenoma. No other abnormalities are noted. He is transferred to the medical floor where laboratory evaluation is significant for increased urine metanephrine levels. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Refer for surgical resection of the adrenal mass
Order magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the adrenal glands
Order US-guided biopsy of the adrenal mass

questions.solution:
This patient presents with intermittent episodes of palpitations and headaches and has resistant hypertension. Increased urine metanephrine levels can be used to diagnose pheochromocytoma and a right adrenal mass was seen on CT. Alpha-adrenergic blockade should be established with oral phenoxybenzamine.

Surgical removal of the adrenal mass is the definitive treatment. In the preoperative period, the goal is to treat hypertension and tachycardia and prevent hypertensive crises from occurring during surgery. Alpha blockade combined with beta-blockade can be prescribed to prevent intraoperative hypertensive crises. It is important to start alpha-blockade, typically with oral phenoxybenzamine, at least 7 days before surgery and before beta blockade. Beta-blockade can be started approximately 2-3 days before surgery. If alpha blockade is not achieved before beta blockers are started, then patients are at risk for worsening hypertension from blockade of vasodilatory peripheral beta-adrenergic receptors with unopposed alpha-adrenergic receptor stimulation.  

Option Analysis

✅ Prescribe oral phenoxybenzamine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Refer for surgical resection of the adrenal mass:
Incorrect: Although surgery is the definitive treatment for pheochromocytoma, it should be performed only after adequate alpha blockade has been established to prevent an intraoperative hypertensive crisis.  
❌ Prescribe oral metoprolol:
Incorrect: Beta-blockers with metoprolol can be used to control tachycardia and hypertension in patients with pheochromocytomas, but they should be started only after adequate alpha blockade has been established. Starting a beta-blocker before alpha blockade has been established can lead to unopposed alpha stimulation and severe hypertension.  
❌ Order magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the adrenal glands:
Incorrect: Further imaging is not necessary at this time, and the patient should be started preoperatively on alpha-adrenergic blockade to prevent an intraoperative hypertensive crisis.  
❌ Order US-guided biopsy of the adrenal mass:
Incorrect: Imaging-guided biopsy is not recommended in patients with a suspected pheochromocytoma because of the elevated risk of complications related to the procedure, including inducing a potential hypertensive crisis.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman comes to the office because of progressive fatigue and weakness for the past six months. She also complains of chronic abdominal pain and dizziness. Past medical history is significant for pulmonary tuberculosis, which was treated completely three years ago. The patient immigrated from China five years ago. Family history is noncontributory. She does not smoke, consume alcohol, or use illicit drugs. Vitals are within normal limits. Laboratory evaluation is shown below. The physician decides to perform a metyrapone stimulation test, as a part of his current research. Which of the following changes will be observed following the administration of metyrapone in this patient?  

Laboratory value
Results
Early morning serum cortisol
2 mcg/dL (normal: 10-20 mcg/dL)
Morning serum ACTH concentration
502 pg/mL (normal: 6-76 pg/mL)
Serum cortisol 30 minutes after the administration of 250 mcg of intravenous cosyntropin
5 mcg/dL
questions.solution:
This patient with chronic fatigue, weakness, dizziness, and nonspecific abdominal pain is likely suffering from a chronic metabolic abnormality. Laboratory findings of decreased serum levels of morning cortisol increased serum ACTH, and the minimal response of cortisol to cosyntropin stimulation makes primary adrenal insufficiency the most likely diagnosis. It might be secondary tuberculous adrenalitis (given her history of tuberculosis) or autoimmune adrenalitis (the most common cause of primary adrenal insufficiency).

Metyrapone is an adrenal hormone synthesis inhibitor that blocks the conversion of 11-deoxycortisol to cortisol by inhibiting the enzyme 11-beta hydroxylase in the zona fasciculata. The metyrapone stimulation test is based on the idea that its administration will decrease serum cortisol levels and increase serum ACTH levels due to the cortisol loss of negative feedback to the hypothalamus. An immediate increase follows in serum 11-deoxycortisol, a cortisol precursor devoid of glucocorticoid activity. It is a sensitive indicator of hypothalamus-pituitary-adrenal axis integrity. Failure of a rise in serum 11-deoxycortisol levels is an indicator of primary or secondary adrenal insufficiency.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Increase in serum cortisol:
Incorrect: Metyrapone inhibits 11-beta-hydroxylase and will result in decreased serum cortisol levels irrespective of the adrenal pathology.  
❌ Decline in serum ACTH levels:
Incorrect: This patient demonstrated a minimal response to the cosyntropin stimulation test (<20µg/dL cortisol). Moreover, her serum ACTH levels are high, making primary adrenal insufficiency the most likely diagnosis. Metyrapone inhibits 11-beta hydroxylase, which, in turn, inhibits the production of cortisol, lifting its negative feedback on ACTH secretion, ultimately causing a further increase in serum ACTH levels.  
❌ Increase in serum renin:
Incorrect: Metyrapone decreases serum aldosterone levels by inhibiting  11-beta-hydroxylase. The mineralocorticoid effect of its precursor 11-deoxycorticosterone prevents the development of mineralocorticoid deficiency. Thus renin levels are rarely affected.  
❌ Decreased serum testosterone:
Incorrect: Metyrapone increases the production of adrenal androgens while inhibiting the production of cortisol. Serum testosterone tends to increase rather than decrease with metyrapone administration.  
✅ Failure of rising in 11-deoxycortisol:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 67-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with new-onset fatigue, nausea, and vomiting for the past day. Her past medical history is significant for rheumatoid arthritis, for which she has taken methotrexate and prednisone for many years. She is visiting from out of town and forgot to pack prednisone for the trip. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 104/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 105/74 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient is oriented to self and place but not time. Mild tenderness is elicited with abdominal palpation. The patient is suspected to be experiencing an acute adrenal crisis. Which of the following laboratory abnormalities would most likely be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Corticosteroids are categorized into three main divisions: glucocorticoids, mineralocorticoids, and androgenic sex hormones. Glucocorticoids are pharmacologically similar to endogenous cortisol. They are used for their anti-inflammatory and immunosuppressive effects. They can be administered orally, intravenously, intramuscularly, or via inhalation.    

The secretion of cortisol is regulated by the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal (HPA) axis. The hypothalamus secretes corticotropin-releasing hormone (CRH), which acts on the pituitary to release adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH). ACTH travels to the adrenal glands, which bind to ACTH on adrenocortical cells. Glucocorticoids are then released from the zona fasciculata of the adrenal gland. Glucocorticoids exert a negative feedback effect on the HPA axis and decrease the release of CRH and ACTH. Chronic use of exogenous glucocorticoids exerts a similar effect on the HPA axis and thus leads to decreased ACTH levels.    

Corticosteroids should never be discontinued abruptly as this can precipitate acute adrenal insufficiency, a medical emergency. The condition can present symptoms including fatigue, anorexia, nausea and vomiting, weakness, hypotension, and circulatory collapse. Treatment includes administering intravenous fluids, glucose, electrolytes, and parenteral glucocorticoids. Full recovery of the HPA axis can take up to one year after cessation of exogenous glucocorticoid use.   

Option Analysis

❌ Decreased potassium level:
Incorrect: This patient has tertiary adrenal crisis secondary to sudden discontinuation of chronic glucocorticoid therapy. This condition affects endogenous glucocorticoid secretion by the adrenal gland but not mineralocorticoid secretion. As a result, potassium levels are likely unaffected in tertiary adrenal insufficiency.
❌ Increased aldosterone level:
Incorrect: This patient has tertiary adrenal crisis secondary to sudden discontinuation of chronic glucocorticoid therapy. This condition affects glucocorticoid secretion by the adrenal gland but not mineralocorticoid secretion. As a result, aldosterone levels will be within normal limits.
❌ Normal corticotropin-releasing hormone (CRH) level:
Incorrect: This patient has been on chronic exogenous glucocorticoid therapy to manage rheumatoid arthritis. The medication leads to suppression of the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis. As a result, this patient most likely has decreased CRH secretion.
✅ Decreased adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) level:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Increased endogenous cortisol level:
Incorrect: Chronic use of exogenous glucocorticoids will suppress the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis and decrease, not increase, endogenous cortisol production.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presents to the primary care clinic because she has noticed easy bruising, amenorrhea, and lower abdominal “stretch marks” that have been present for the past six months. Past medical history is significant for rheumatoid arthritis and poorly controlled ulcerative colitis. Current medications include celecoxib, methotrexate, and high-dose prednisone. She has been on moderate to high doses of steroids for over three months. Vital signs are taken by the nurse and are not yet available for review. On physical examination, supraclavicular and dorsocervical fat pads are enlarged. The abdomen is obese with violaceous striae. Which of the following combination of findings would be expected given the likely underlying diagnosis?

choices.text: Thickened skin and enlargement of muscles of the extremities
Loss of abdominal fat and hirsutism

questions.solution:
This patient who has been on chronic moderate to high-dose steroids presents with easy bruising, amenorrhea, and new violaceous striae on the abdomen. These findings are concerning for Cushing syndrome, which can be due to the use of exogenous corticosteroids. Hypertension and polyuria from hyperglycemia secondary to glucose intolerance or uncontrolled DM can be seen in patients presenting with Cushing syndrome.

Cushing syndrome results from long-term exposure to high glucocorticoid levels in the blood. This can be secondary to exogenous glucocorticoids (e.g. from chronic corticosteroid use) or endogenous glucocorticoids (e.g. from adrenal hypersecretion of corticosteroids, pituitary hypersecretion of adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH)).

Patients can present with mood changes (e.g. irritability), signs and symptoms consistent with glucose intolerance or diabetes mellitus (e.g. polyuria), hypertension, skin findings (e.g. thinning skin, violaceous abdominal striae), and body composition changes (e.g. buffalo hump, moon facies or facial plethora, central obesity, extremity wasting). An enlarged dorsocervical fat pad (also known as a “buffalo hump”), moon facies or facial plethora, and central obesity result from fat redistribution from the effects of glucocorticoids. Proximal muscle weakness and wasting of the extremities results from glucocorticoid-mediated protein degradation. High glucocorticoid levels can also suppress gonadotropin secretion, leading to decreased libido or amenorrhea.  

Option Analysis

✅ Hypertension and polyuria:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Hypotension and polyuria:
Incorrect: Patients with Cushing syndrome can present with hypertension due to cortisol’s effects on blood pressure and signs of hyperglycemia (e.g. polyuria) from the development of glucose intolerance or diabetes mellitus. Hypotension is not typically associated with Cushing syndrome.  
❌ Thickened skin and enlargement of muscles of the extremities:
Incorrect: Cushing syndrome is associated with several skin findings and body composition changes, including thinning skin, proximal muscle weakness, and wasting of the extremities.  
❌ Loss of abdominal fat and hirsutism:
Incorrect: Cushing syndrome can lead to hirsutism, central obesity, and extremity wasting. Abdominal fat is increased in patients with Cushing syndrome.  
❌ Hirsutism and decreased urinary frequency  :
Incorrect: Patients with Cushing syndrome typically present with findings of hypertension and  signs and symptoms of hyperglycemia from glucose intolerance or uncontrolled DM (e.g. polyuria and polydipsia). Decreased urinary frequency would not be expected.

questions.text: A 46-year-old man presents to the endocrinology clinic for suspected Cushing syndrome. Over the past year, the patient has developed thin skin, easy bruising, central obesity, and abdominal striae. Past medical history is otherwise unremarkable, and the patient takes no medications. Temperature is 37.0ºC (98.6ºF), blood pressure is 149/92 mmHg, respiratory rate is 14/min, and pulse is 84/min. On physical examination, the patient has moon facies, central obesity, and violaceous abdominal striae. Late-night salivary cortisol and 24-hour urinary free cortisol levels are elevated. Serum adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) is low. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents to the endocrinologist with signs and symptoms of Cushing syndrome. The absence of exogenous glucocorticoid use and the elevated late-night salivary and 24-hour urinary free cortisol levels support a diagnosis of Cushing syndrome secondary to an endogenous source. The low adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) level indicates ACTH-independent Cushing syndrome, which is caused by adrenal cortisol hypersecretion either from adrenal hyperplasia or an adrenal mass. Further adrenal imaging should be performed to confirm the underlying cause.

Cushing syndrome is a syndrome resulting from long-term exposure to high glucocorticoid levels in the blood. This can be exogenous (e.g. chronic corticosteroid use) or endogenous (e.g. adrenal hypersecretion of corticosteroids, pituitary hypersecretion of ACTH). If patients have elevated cortisol levels demonstrated on late-night salivary cortisol or 24-hour urine free cortisol testing or they have an abnormal dexamethasone suppression test, then endogenous Cushing syndrome is confirmed. ACTH levels should be checked next to determine if ACTH-dependent or ACTH-independent Cushing syndrome is present.
 



Option Analysis

✅ Adrenal hyperplasia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Iatrogenic Cushing syndrome:
Incorrect: This patient is not taking exogenous glucocorticoids and, therefore, does not have an iatrogenic cause of Cushing syndrome. An endogenous source of cortisol (e.g. adrenal tumor or adrenal hyperplasia) is the more likely cause.  
❌ Small cell lung cancer:
Incorrect: Given the low ACTH, this patient has ACTH-independent Cushing syndrome (i.e. adrenal hyperplasia). Patients with small cell lung cancer can have ectopic ACTH production, which leads to ACTH-dependent Cushing syndrome with elevated ACTH levels.  
❌ Pituitary macroadenoma:
Incorrect: This patient has ACTH-independent Cushing syndrome, which can be caused by adrenal hyperplasia. Pituitary tumors can cause ACTH-dependent disease. Patients found to have elevated ACTH levels and ACTH-dependent Cushing syndrome should have a pituitary MRI and possibly inferior petrosal sinus sampling to diagnose the cause of ACTH overproduction.  
❌ Pituitary microadenoma:
Incorrect: This patient has ACTH-independent Cushing syndrome, which can be caused by adrenal hyperplasia. Pituitary tumors can cause ACTH-dependent disease. Patients found to have elevated ACTH levels and ACTH-dependent Cushing syndrome should have a pituitary MRI and possibly inferior petrosal sinus sampling to diagnose the cause of ACTH overproduction.

questions.text: A 3-week-old girl is brought to the pediatrician by her parents for evaluation of vomiting and diarrhea. Over the past week, the infant has had an increasing frequency of vomiting and diarrhea, and she is now less alert and not feeding well. The infant was born at 39 weeks' gestation to a G1P0 mother. Prenatal course was uncomplicated, and the mother received all recommended prenatal care. Noninvasive prenatal testing (NIPT) performed at 10 weeks' gestation was normal. Weight is at the 12th percentile and the patient has not yet returned to birth weight. Temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 160/min, respirations are 38/min, and oxygen saturation is 100% on room air. On physical examination, the patient appears fatigued, and she is lying in her parent’s arms. The anterior fontanelle is slightly sunken, and the lips are dry. Cardiopulmonary examination is normal. On genitourinary examination, there is clitoral enlargement, labial fusion, and a urogenital sinus. An in-office glucose level is 42. Which of the following should be ordered next to confirm the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This 3-week-old patient presents with worsening vomiting and diarrhea and is now dehydrated and hypoglycemic. Physical examination findings reveal ambiguous genitalia. This presentation is suspicious for congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) which can be diagnosed if there is an elevated 17-hydroxyprogesterone level.      

Many causes of vomiting in newborns and infants can be diagnosed clinically. Viral gastroenteritis, food protein induced enterocolitis syndrome, and gastroesophageal reflux are typically diagnosed by history and physical examination alone. Imaging is necessary when there is concern that the underlying cause of vomiting is a structural abnormality. Intestinal malrotation with volvulus can be diagnosed if there is the finding of a “corkscrew” appearance of the duodenum on upper gastrointestinal contrast study. A “target sign” or “donut sign” will be present on abdominal ultrasound in patients with intussusception. While not an anatomical abnormality, the diagnosis of necrotizing enterocolitis can be supported by the finding of pneumatosis intestinalis on abdominal radiograph.       

Laboratory studies are often necessary when evaluating a newborn or infant who presents with vomiting. When a female or uncircumcised male presents with fever (without other symptoms) or urinary symptoms, urine studies should be obtained to confirm the diagnosis as untreated urinary tract infections can lead to vomiting. Genetic causes of vomiting such as inborn errors of metabolism and congenital adrenal hyperplasia are often detected on newborn screening. However, these results should be confirmed with additional tests such as serum amino acid levels, urine organic acids, or 17-hydroxyprogesterone, depending on the patient’s symptoms.   

Option Analysis

✅ 17-hydroxyprogesterone level:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Karyotype:
Incorrect: This patient’s presentation of worsening vomiting and diarrhea in the setting of ambiguous genitalia is consistent with congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH). This condition is diagnosed by the finding of an elevated 17-hydroxyprogesterone level. A karyotype would help confirm this patient’s sex but would not confirm the diagnosis of CAH. 
❌ Ammonia level:
Incorrect: This patient’s presentation of worsening vomiting and diarrhea in the setting of ambiguous genitalia is consistent with congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) which can be diagnosed by the finding of an elevated 17-hydroxyprogesterone level. Elevated ammonia levels are nonspecific but can be present in patients with inborn errors of metabolism such as in urea cycle disorders. Urea cycle disorders are not associated with ambiguous genitalia. 
❌ Cosyntropin (ACTH) stimulation test:
Incorrect: This patient’s presentation of worsening vomiting and diarrhea in the setting of ambiguous genitalia is consistent with congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH). This condition is diagnosed by detection of an elevated 17-hydroxyprogesterone level. An ACTH stimulation test is often used to measure the ability of the adrenal glands to respond to ACTH and produce cortisol. An ACTH stimulation test is used if results are equivocal after checking 17-hydroxyprogesterone levels in patients where there is high suspicion for CAH. 
❌ Pelvic ultrasound:
Incorrect: This patient’s presentation of worsening vomiting and diarrhea in the setting of ambiguous genitalia is consistent with congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH). It is diagnosed by elevated the finding of an elevated 17-hydroxyprogesterone level. A pelvic ultrasound would help confirm this patient’s sex but would not confirm the diagnosis of CAH.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman presents to the office to evaluate episodic headaches, which have been ongoing for  two months. The headache is bilateral, throbbing, and 10 out of 10 in severity. The headaches last for 10-15 minutes, accompanied by generalized sweating and palpitations, and subsequently resolve spontaneously. Past medical history is noncontributory. Family history is significant for thyroid cancer in her mother at 30. She smokes a pack of cigarettes daily and does not consume alcohol or illicit substances. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 85/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 158/89 mmHg. Physical examination is unremarkable. Laboratory evaluation reveals elevated plasma metanephrines. An abdomen CT reveals a 4 cm adrenal mass without evidence of metastasis. Surgical resection of the mass is scheduled for the following week, and a preoperative drug is administered during the current visit. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of this drug?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with episodic headaches, palpitations, elevated plasma metanephrines, and a 4 cm adrenal mass imaging. These findings indicate a pheochromocytoma, which is a catecholamine secreting tumor of the adrenal medulla. To prevent intraoperative catecholamine crisis, the patient should be started on a non-selective ɑ-adrenergic antagonist.   

Non-selective ɑ-blockers work by blocking both ɑ1 and ɑ2 adrenergic receptors and include phenoxybenzamine and phentolamine. ɑ1 blockade causes vasodilation, resulting in a lowering of blood pressure. Phenoxybenzamine is an irreversible ɑ-blocker that is administered at least one to two weeks before the resection of a pheochromocytoma to prevent a catecholamine crisis during surgery. It binds to a different site on the receptor from catecholamines. It alters the receptor's shape so that it can no longer bind to catecholamines released from the adrenal medulla.  

On the other hand, phentolamine is a reversible inhibitor. It is primarily indicated to treat  hypertensive crises in patients who co-ingested a monoamine oxidase inhibitor with tyramine-containing foods (e.g., cheese, wine, beer).  

Common side effects of these medications include orthostatic hypotension and reflex tachycardia.  

Option Analysis

❌ ɑ1-receptor antagonist :
Incorrect: ɑ1-receptor antagonists (e.g., prazosin, doxazosin) can sometimes be used to improve the symptoms of a metastatic pheochromocytoma that is not amenable to surgical resection. However, for surgical candidates, phenoxybenzamine is the preferred drug for preoperative blood pressure control and the prevention of arrhythmias.  
✅ Non-selective ɑ-receptor antagonist:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor:
Incorrect: This patient’s blood pressure is elevated secondary to a pheochromocytoma. The patient should be pretreated with an irreversible non-selective ɑ-blocker to reduce the incidence of a catecholamine crisis during surgery.  
❌ β-adrenergic blocker:
Incorrect: This patient has a pheochromocytoma, and β-adrenergic blockers should not be administered before ɑ-adrenergic antagonists. Otherwise, the patient is at risk of unopposed ɑ-adrenergic receptor stimulation, further exacerbating the patient’s hypertension.  
❌ Muscarinic receptor antagonist:
Incorrect: Preoperative administration of a muscarinic receptor antagonist would not alter the patient’s vascular tone. It may, however, increase the patient’s heart rate and further increase blood pressure.

questions.text:
A 49-year-old woman is admitted to the hospital for a right femoral neck fracture after falling from standing height. The patient had surgical fixation with no intraoperative complications. Several hours later, she developed hypotension. Her past medical history is significant for severe active rheumatoid arthritis. The patient cannot recall her home medications. Temperature is 36.1 ºC (97.0 ºF), pulse is 98/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, blood pressure is 77/42 mmHg, and SpO2 is 98% on room air. The patient is given two liters of normal saline solution. A repeat blood pressure is 83/47 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient is lethargic. Mucous membranes are moist. Cardiopulmonary auscultation is unremarkable. Electrocardiogram shows normal sinus rhythm without ST segment or T wave changes. Bloodwork is obtained and shown below. Which of the following is most likely to be found on further examination or history?

Laboratory Test  
Result
Troponin I  
< 0.04 ng/mL  
Sodium
127 mEq/L  
Potassium
5.6 mEq/L

19 mEq/L

questions.solution:
This patient developed postoperative hypotension that is refractory to IV fluids. The fact that this patient has severe active rheumatoid arthritis and a fragility fracture (ie fracture in young patient secondary to fall from standing height) likely indicates chronic steroid use. The additional laboratory findings of hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, and metabolic acidosis suggest adrenal crisis, which can be secondary to abrupt discontinuation of chronic steroids.

Adrenal crisis typically occurs in the setting of acute stress (e.g., severe infection, surgery) in patients with underlying primary adrenal insufficiency or after abrupt cessation of glucocorticoids even if preoperative steroids are given. Patients present with hypotension and may also be lethargic, as seen in this patient, and have vague abdominal discomfort. Laboratory studies may show hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, and metabolic acidosis due to low mineralocorticoid activity. Treatment with stress-dose IV steroids should be started in patients with suspected adrenal crisis and should not be delayed to obtain confirmatory laboratory studies.  

Option Analysis

✅ Chronic steroid use:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Surreptitious diuretic use:
Incorrect: While diuretic overuse could cause hyponatremia and hypotension, this patient’s hyperkalemia and moist mucous membranes point away from this. Adrenal crisis from the abrupt discontinuation of chronic steroids is more likely.  
❌ Wheezing:
Incorrect: Wheezing and hypotension in the postoperative period could indicate anaphylaxis. This patient has no flushing, hives, or oropharyngeal swelling to suggest anaphylaxis. Adrenal crisis from the abrupt discontinuation of chronic steroids is more likely.  
❌ Hemoptysis:
Incorrect: Hemoptysis can occasionally occur in patients with pulmonary embolism and significant tissue infarction. If a pulmonary embolism is large enough to cause hypotension and pulmonary infarction, it would generally cause dyspnea and hypoxia which are not present in this patient. Adrenal crisis from the abrupt discontinuation of chronic steroids is more likely.  
❌ Muffled heart sounds:
Incorrect: Muffled heart sounds can occur secondary to moderate or large pericardial effusions and could indicate cardiac tamponade in a patient with hypotension. However, other signs would likely be present (e.g. jugular venous distention, electrical alternans, and/or low QRS voltage on ECG). These findings are absent in this patient and the findings that are seen are more likely due to adrenal crisis from the abrupt discontinuation of chronic steroids.

An 18-year-old woman comes to the emergency department complaining of nausea and flank pain. Over the past 24 hours, she developed pain in her right flan,k along with fevers and several episodes of non-bilious, non-bloody vomiting. She has a history of type 1 diabetes mellitus and uses an insulin pump which is currently in place and appears to be functioning properly. The patient’s temperature is 38.9°C (102°F), pulse is 115/min, respirations are 25/min, and blood pressure is 95/60 mmHg. Physical examination shows a thin, uncomfortable woman with legs flexed to her chest in the right lateral decubitus position. She is breathing deeply. Lightly tapping over her right lower back causes her to jump in pain. Sensation to light touch is diminished on the plantar surfaces of both feet. Laboratory studies show the following:  
 
Laboratory value Result 
Hemoglobin  12 g/dL 
 Hematocrit  36 % 
 Leukocyte count  16,000/mm3 
 Platelet count  400,000/mm3 
 Sodium  130 mEq/L 
 Potassium  5.0 mEq/L 
 Chloride  100 mEq/L 
 Bicarbonate  14 mEq/L 
 Blood urea nitrogen  15 mg/dL 
 Creatinine  1.0 mg/dL 
 Glucose  500 mg/dL 
Which of the following solutes is most important to replenish at this point in time?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with signs and symptoms of pyelonephritis in the setting of well-controlled type 1 diabetes mellitus with evidence of chronic peripheral neuropathy (extremity numbness). Pyelonephritis, or an infection of the kidney, is more common in diabetic patients and causes nausea, vomiting, fever, leukocytosis, and flank pain with costovertebral tenderness on physical examination. Although this patient’s diabetes has stably been controlled on her insulin pump, infections increase the body’s insulin requirement and are thus a common trigger for diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA). Without any insulin, lipolysis occurs and the liver starts to turn fatty acids into ketone bodies, such as aceto-acetic acid and beta hydroxybutyric acid, thereby increasing the acidity of the blood, causing an anion-gap metabolic acidosis.   

Clinically, individuals with DKA are dehydrated from hyperglycemic polyuria. The acidosis causes Kussmaul respiration, which is deep and rapid breathing as the body tries to move carbon dioxide out of the blood to reduce its acidity. Abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and mental status changes like delirium and psychosis can occur. Laboratory results show hyperglycemia with low serum pH and low bicarbonate. The anion gap is high, which reflects a large difference in the unmeasured negative and positive ions in the serum, largely due to this build up of ketoacids.  

Potassium is critically important to replete in DKA. Recall that cells have a transporter that exchanges hydrogen ions for potassium. When the blood gets acidic, there are many positively charged hydrogen ions present in the blood. Cells will exchange these extracellular protons with intracellular potassium, so initially there will be hyperkalemia. In addition to helping glucose enter cells, insulin also stimulates the sodium-potassium ATPases that help potassium get into cells; without insulin, more potassium stays in the extracellular fluid. Since this extracellular potassium is quickly excreted, even though the blood potassium levels remain high, total body potassium is depleted. Therefore, treatment of DKA relies on IV fluids to correct dehydration, IV insulin to reverse lipolysis, and aggressive potassium repletion as soon as serum potassium levels are in the normal range.  



Option Analysis

❌ Sodium:
Incorrect: An increase in extracellular glucose concentration moves water out of cells, causing dilution of extracellular sodium and a falsely low serum sodium level on lab values. For every 100 mg/dL of glucose over 100, you can expect a 1.6 drop in sodium. This patient’s corrected sodium level is normal at 136 mEq/L.  
✅ Potassium:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Chloride:
Incorrect: Serum chloride levels are usually normal in patients with diabetic ketoacidosis and do not require focused repletion beyond what is given in isotonic fluids.   
❌ Bicarbonate:
Incorrect: Although this patient’s bicarbonate is low, indicating diabetic ketoacidosis, the proper way to fix it is by treating the underlying cause with insulin and intravenous fluids. Clinical trials do not support the routine use of bicarbonate replacement in diabetic ketoacidosis.  
❌ Glucose:
Incorrect: Treating diabetic ketoacidosis requires insulin to allow the body to process all of the built up extracellular glucose. Only once the plasma glucose reaches 200-250 mg/dL is glucose added to the insulin infusion to prevent massive drops in serum glucose, which can cause cerebral edema.

A 55-year-old man comes to the emergency department with fevers and a cough for the past week. The fever is intermittent and associated with a dull headache. The cough is non-productive, and the patient denies sore throat, nasal congestion, shortness of breath, or chest pain. He has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus diagnosed 5 years ago. Initially, the patient was prescribed oral antihyperglycemics, but he switched to herbal remedies after one month because of side effects. The patient has never smoked cigarettes. He is employed as a groundskeeper at a local country club. The patient’s temperature is 36.4°C (97.5°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 120/70 mmHg. Physical examination shows occasional coarse left-sided crackles on lung auscultation. Neurologic and skin examinations are normal. Serum laboratory studies show the following:  
 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 White blood cells  28,000 /mm3 
 Creatinine  2.3 mg/dL 
 Glucose  374 mg/dL 
 Bicarbonate  19 mEq/L 
 Ketones  Positive 
Chest X-ray shows homogenous opacities in the left upper lobe. Nasal endoscopy shows extensive inflammation of the left nasal cavity and maxillary sinus. Sputum microscopy shows the following:  


 Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons  

Which of the following antimicrobial agents is most appropriate to administer to this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient’s findings of fever, leukocytosis, headache, and cough, along with pulmonary opacities and hyphal elements on sputum, suggest a diagnosis of a disseminated fungal infection. Additionally, this patient has a history of uncontrolled diabetes with ketosis and acidosis on laboratory studies. Patients with diabetic ketoacidosis are uniquely at high risk of acquiring mucormycosis, while patients with normal immune function are almost never infected.  

Under the order of Mucorales, the most common genuses that cause human infection are Rhizopus and Mucor. They are ubiquitous in the environment. Their hyphae are broad, irregularly branched (at 90º), and have rare septations. Aspergillus, by contrast, has narrow hyphae with regular branching (at 45º) and many septations. Intravenous amphotericin B is the initial drug of choice to treat mucormycosis. Second line drugs include posaconazole or isavuconazole. Even with appropriate antifungal therapy, mortality from mucormycosis approaches 80%.  

Besides mucormycosis, patients with diabetes are at higher risk of acquiring bacterial and fungal infections in general. The attributable mechanisms include the following: 1) decreased neutrophil chemotaxis and adherence, 2) vascular insufficiency depressing the oxygen-dependent bactericidal functions of leukocytes, 3) sensory peripheral neuropathy predisposing to skin lesions, 4) autonomic neuropathy causing urinary stasis, and 5) increased skin and mucosal colonization with pathogens.  

Option Analysis

✅ Amphotericin B:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Ceftazidime:
Incorrect: Ceftazidime (a third-generation cephalosporin) is the antibacterial agent of choice to treat melioidosis (infection with the gram-negative bacterium Burkholderia pseudomallei). The most common symptoms are pneumonia and skin infections. Diabetic patients are at risk for this infection because of their impaired ability to kill Burkholderia via macrophages; however, this patient’s sputum microscopy shows a different organism. 
❌ Fluconazole:
Incorrect: Fluconazole is a hydrophilic azole used to treat candidal infections, and is commonly used to treat vulvovaginal candidiasis in women. Diabetic patients are particularly susceptible to infections with Candida albicans because glucose activates its adhesion proteins, allowing it to attach to the vaginal epithelium and evade phagocytosis.
❌ Isavuconazonium :
Incorrect: Isavuconazonium is a prodrug that is rapidly hydrolyzed in the blood to the active azole isavuconazole. It is most commonly used in the treatment and prevention of invasive aspergillosis, although it can be used as a second-line medication in the treatment of mucormycosis, if treatment with amphotericin B is unsuccessful.
❌ Nitrofurantoin:
Incorrect: Nitrofurantoin is an antibiotic that is reduced by bacterial flavoproteins into intermediates which halt bacterial metabolism. It is used commonly in the treatment of simple acute cystitis, which is most often caused by Escherichia coli. Diabetic patients are at risk for this infection because of the formation of glycation end products that enhance bacterial binding to the bladder urothelium.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old man comes to the clinic complaining of excessive urination. He says that for the past month he has needed to urinate every two hours, including at night, and as a result is drinking a lot more water. He has felt hungrier than usual but has not been gaining any weight. He does not have any pain with urination, and he denies fevers or night sweats. He does not have any medical history but he notes that he has not seen a doctor in 20 years. His temperature is 36.7°C (98.0°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 150/100 mmHg. BMI is 38 kg/m2. Physical examination shows no lymphadenopathy; his prostate is symmetric and mildly enlarged. Laboratory tests show the following:  
 
Laboratory value  Result 
 Serum 
 Blood urea nitrogen  30 mg/dL 
 Creatinine  1.8 mg/dL 
 Hemoglobin A1c  10.5 % 
 Urine  
 Albumin  400 mg/g 
What is the effect of the drug most likely to prevent this patient’s progression to end-stage-kidney disease?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with the classic symptoms of uncontrolled diabetes: polyuria, polydipsia, and polyphagia without weight gain. The diagnosis of type 2 diabetes is confirmed by his hemoglobin A1c greater than 6.4%. He also has hypertension and obesity, reflective of metabolic syndrome. His laboratory studies show an elevated creatinine with a relatively normal blood urea nitrogen (ratio of BUN/Cr less than 20:1), suggesting intrinsic diabetic kidney disease.  

Diabetic kidney disease (also known as diabetic nephropathy) occurs in the setting of non-enzymatic glycosylation, in which glucose covalently attaches to cell proteins and lipids. These sugar coated molecules are pro-inflammatory and can cause damage to the cell. In the kidneys, the afferent and efferent arterioles, as well as the glomerulus itself, can be damaged, which can lead to nodular glomerulosclerosis.  On histology, there are characteristic Kimmelstiel-Wilson nodules, which are clumps of hyaline material found in glomerular capillaries.    

In the early stages of diabetic nephropathy, small amounts of albumin leak through the glomerular barrier and into the urine. Once the leak grows larger, to 300 mg/g of albumin excretion on urinalysis, studies show that taking an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE)-inhibitor significantly reduces the risk of death and progression to end-stage kidney disease (dialysis). ACE-inhibitors work by blocking the conversion of angiotensin I to angiotensin II. Because angiotensin II causes efferent glomerular arteriole vasoconstriction, decreasing it results in efferent vasodilation. This vasodilation reduces upstream afferent arteriole pressure, which, if left unchecked, compounds the damage from hyperglycemia and leads to kidney disease progression.  



Option Analysis

❌ Afferent arteriole vasodilation:
Incorrect: The afferent glomerular arteriole is dilated by prostacyclins and prostaglandins like PGI2 and PGE2. Although prostacyclins are used to treat pulmonary arterial hypertension, they are not used to modulate renal outcomes in patients with diabetes.
❌ Afferent arteriole constriction:
Incorrect: Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory medications (NSAIDS) inhibit the production of vasodilatory prostaglandins, leading to afferent glomerular arteriole constriction. This decreases the glomerular filtration rate, leading to activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system, which should be avoided in patients with hypertension or kidney disease.
✅ Efferent arteriole vasodilation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Efferent arteriole vasoconstriction:
Incorrect: Angiotensin II is the main driver of efferent glomerular arteriole constriction. Low volume states like hypotension or hemorrhage will trigger the juxtaglomerular apparatus to release renin, culminating in angiotensin II production, which maintains blood flow through the kidneys. 
❌ Basement membrane thickening:
Incorrect: Glomerular basement membrane thickening is commonly seen in patients with diabetes. This pathologic process is caused by direct damage from hyperglycemia and may eventually result in glomerular scarring known as tubulointerstitial fibrosis. Tubulointerstitial fibrosis is a harbinger of end-stage kidney disease.

questions.text: A 36 year old man presents to the office for a routine physical after recently acquiring medical insurance through his employer. He has no known medical problems. He has been more easily fatigued the past 8 months and noticed increased thirst and urination. Family history is significant for diabetes mellitus, type 2 in his mother, father, older brother and paternal grandparents. He eats out for most of his meals and does not exercise. Blood pressure is 140/85 mmHg, pulse is 84/minute, and BMI is 35. Cardiac and pulmonary examinations are unremarkable. Which of the following physical examination findings may be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presents for a routine physical examination. History reveals easy fatigability, polyuria, polydipsia, family history for diabetes mellitus, type 2, sedentary lifestyle and an unhealthy diet, supporting a diagnosis of type 2 diabetes mellitus. Patients with diabetes mellitus may present with physical examination findings that include obesity, acanthosis nigricans, vision loss, and diminished sensation to pinprick in the distal extremities. Acanthosis nigricans is a disorder of the skin characterized by hyperpigmented, velvety patches most commonly found in intertriginous sites such as the neck, axilla and groin. It is associated with conditions characterized by insulin resistance such as diabetes mellitus, type 2.
 

Acanthosis nigricans in axilla
Image reproduced from Wikimedia commons  

Acanthosis Nigricans on neck
Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

Classic symptoms of diabetes mellitus include polydipsia (excessive thirst), polyuria (excessive urination), polyphagia (excessive eating) and unintentional weight loss. Some patients may present with symptoms from complications secondary to diabetes mellitus such as retinopathy, nephropathy, neuropathy, impotence or frequent bacterial or fungal infections.

In patients presenting with symptoms of numbness and tingling in the feet, physical examination findings of diminished sensation with a monofilament test supports the diagnosis of diabetic neuropathy. Patients presenting with vision changes such as blurry vision or vision loss should be evaluated further with a fundoscopic examination to evaluate for signs of diabetic retinopathy such as cotton-wool spots, hemorrhages, and hard exudates.  

Option Analysis

✅ Acanthosis nigricans:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Xanthomas:
Incorrect: Xanthomas are lipid deposits within the skin that can present in patients with hyperlipidemia. This patient is presenting with symptoms and family history that support a diagnosis of diabetes mellitus.  
❌ Lichen planus:
Incorrect: Lichen planus is a chronic disease affecting the skin and mucous membranes that can be seen in patients with metabolic syndrome. Dyslipidemia is found to be significantly higher in patients with lichen planus.  
❌ Atopic dermatitis:
Incorrect: Atopic dermatitis is a chronic, pruritic, inflammatory skin condition that has been found to be associated with elevated triglycerides.  
❌ Lipoma:
Incorrect: A lipoma is a benign skin lesion that is composed of fat cells, usually in the subcutaneous tissue. It is not associated with diabetes mellitus.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for nausea, vomiting, and diffuse abdominal pain. Her husband states that she has had increased thirst and urination recently. She has a history of poorly-controlled type 1 diabetes mellitus. Temperature is 37.2 °C (99 °F), blood pressure is 94/68 mmHg, pulse is 120/min, respiratory rate is 22/min, and oxygen saturation is 100% on room air. She is disoriented and sleepy. On examination, her mucous membranes are dry, and her respirations are quick and deep. A point-of-care glucose level is 400 mg/dL. Which of the following physical examination findings would also be expected in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient’s history, examination, and hyperglycemia are consistent with diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA). DKA is a life-threatening complication of diabetes caused by a deficiency of insulin and an excess of glucagon. This results in hyperglycemia and ketosis, which leads to osmotic diuresis and volume depletion.
 

The patient's history will typically include a history of diabetes mellitus (most commonly type 1, where there is an absolute lack of endogenous insulin production). There may also be indications of a precipitating cause (e.g., missed insulin dose, infection, or other acute illness). Symptoms are typically related to the underlying disease process and may include polydipsia, polyuria, diffuse abdominal pain, fatigue, disorientation, and somnolence.

On examination, signs of volume depletion may include dry mucous membranes, tachycardia, and hypotension. The underlying ketosis and high anion gap metabolic acidosis can lead to quick, deep breaths, called Kussmaul respirations, and a fruity odor to the patient’s breath, also called acetone breath, due to the excessive production of ketones. The physical examination may also provide clues to any precipitating factors (e.g., infection, stroke).  

Option Analysis

✅ Fruity odor to her breath:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Asterixis:
Incorrect: Asterixis can be seen in multiple conditions, such as hepatic encephalopathy as well as hypercapnia. This patient’s history and examination are more consistent with diabetic ketoacidosis, which is not associated with asterixis.  
❌ Tenderness at McBurney’s point:
Incorrect: Tenderness at McBurney’s point occurs in cases of appendicitis, which can cause abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. However, this patient’s history of type 1 diabetes, polyuria, polydipsia, and hyperglycemia are more consistent with diabetic ketoacidosis.  
❌ Jaundice:
Incorrect: Jaundice can occur in multiple liver disorders, such as hepatitis and cirrhosis. However, this patient’s history and examination are more consistent with diabetic ketoacidosis.  
❌ Suprapubic tenderness:
Incorrect: Suprapubic tenderness can occur in urinary tract infections, which can manifest as fever, urinary frequency, nausea, and potential signs of sepsis. However, this patient’s history of type 1 diabetes, polydipsia, hyperglycemia, and Kussmaul respirations are more consistent with diabetic ketoacidosis.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old man is admitted to the hospital for management of diabetic ketoacidosis. He is given aggressive IV fluid resuscitation with normal saline, an IV bolus of regular insulin, and placed on a continuous insulin infusion. After initial management, his disorientation and abdominal discomfort have resolved; however, he continues to have mild nausea. Temperature is 39.2 °C (102.5 °F), blood pressure is 88/62 mmHg, pulse is 130/min, respiratory rate is 24/min, and oxygen saturation is 100% on room air. His fluid was changed to 5% dextrose in half-normal saline 2 hours ago. The most recent laboratory studies are listed below. Which of the following adjustments should be made to the current management?  

Laboratory study
Result

140 mEq/L

4.0 mEq/L

10 mEq/L

Venous pH

choices.text: Add potassium to the IV fluid
Add sodium bicarbonate to the IV fluid

questions.solution:
Management of diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) typically requires insulin administration and IV fluid resuscitation. IV insulin not only decreases serum glucose levels by allowing the uptake of glucose into cells, but it also inhibits ketogenesis. The ketones in the system are then cleared through the kidneys. IV fluid is important in the correction of volume depletion, which is caused by osmotic diuresis in DKA. Oftentimes, the patient’s blood glucose level will correct before their high anion gap metabolic acidosis resolves. In this circumstance, dextrose is added to the IV fluid while the patient remains on the insulin infusion in order to prevent hypoglycemia.

Additionally, electrolyte monitoring and management of abnormalities is an essential part of the management of DKA. In DKA, potassium shifts out of cells due to metabolic acidosis, and some potassium then leaves the body through the kidneys. In laboratory studies, the serum potassium may appear high or normal despite the overall deficiency. As insulin is infused and the acidosis is corrected, potassium shifts back into the cells and can lead to hypokalemia. Thus, it is important to monitor and provide potassium supplementation to prevent dangerous complications resulting from hypokalemia.

Laboratory studies, including electrolytes, are typically monitored every 2–4 hours during the treatment period for DKA. If the potassium level is above the reference range, no replacement is required (but monitoring should still continue). In cases where the potassium level drops below the reference range, insulin should be temporarily held until adequate replacement is achieved. Even levels within the normal range require supplementation. However, this can easily be achieved by adding potassium to the patient’s IV fluid without disrupting the continuous insulin infusion.

Once the patient’s glucose is stabilized and the high anion gap acidosis has resolved, the patient can be transitioned to subcutaneous insulin. This usually requires a 1–2 hour overlap between IV insulin and subcutaneous insulin, with close monitoring of blood glucose levels.  

Option Analysis

❌ Continue 5% dextrose in half-normal saline:
Incorrect: Despite the patient’s normal potassium, he still has a high anion gap metabolic acidosis. With the continued insulin infusion and correction of the acidosis, additional potassium supplementation will be needed.  
✅ Add potassium to the IV fluid:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Discontinue IV fluids:
Incorrect: This patient is still in diabetic ketoacidosis, as evidenced by the high anion gap metabolic acidosis. Continued insulin and IV fluid hydration are needed.  
❌ Discontinue the insulin infusion:
Incorrect: Despite the fact that the patient’s glucose is <200 mg/dL, he is still in diabetic ketoacidosis, as evidenced by the high anion gap metabolic acidosis. Continued insulin and IV fluid hydration are needed.  
❌ Add sodium bicarbonate to the IV fluid:
Incorrect: Sodium bicarbonate is typically only required in severe acidosis where the patient’s blood pH is <6.9. Management of acidosis in DKA centers around treating the underlying insulin deficiency causing the excess ketone production.

questions.text: A 19-year-old man presents to the primary care clinic with a 1-month history of fatigue, and a 5 kg (11.1lbs) unintentional weight loss. He reports that he has been drinking 4 liters of water per day and that he has been urinating more often than usual. He denies any recent illness or stress. Past medical history is unremarkable, and the patient is not taking any medications. Family history is significant for Grave disease and vitiligo in his mother. BMI is 31 kg/m<sup>2</sup>. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination is unremarkable. Initial laboratory evaluation is significant for a random plasma glucose level of 260 mg/dL. Which of the following is the best next step in evaluation?

choices.text: Order C-peptide and GAD65 antibody levels
Refer for nutrition and exercise counseling

questions.solution:
This patient presents with polyuria, polydipsia, unintentional weight loss, and an elevated random blood glucose level, all of which are consistent with the diagnosis of diabetes mellitus. He has a BMI of 31 kg/m2, which places him in the obese category, raising suspicion for type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM). However, his young age and family history of autoimmune diseases increase the likelihood of type 1 diabetes mellitus (T1DM). Therefore, the best next step in the evaluation is to order C-peptide and GAD65 antibody levels in order to distinguish between these two types of diabetes, as management differs.
 

In a symptomatic patient with classical symptoms of hyperglycemia, the diagnosis of diabetes mellitus can be made if a random blood glucose level is ≥200 mg/dL. In asymptomatic patients, the diagnosis of diabetes can be established if 2 of the following are present: fasting plasma glucose (FPG) ≥126 mg/dL, two-hour plasma glucose ≥200 mg/dL during an oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT), or HbA1C ≥6.5%. In an asymptomatic patient if HbA1c ranges between 5.7 and 6.5%, FBG is between 100 and 126 mg/dL, or blood glucose after the 2-hour OGTT is between 140 and 199 mg/dL, and a random blood glucose is <200 mg/dL, prediabetes can be diagnosed. Prediabetes typically precedes type 2 diabetes mellitus and rarely precedes type 1.

Following a diagnosis of diabetes mellitus, the next step is to determine the underlying mechanism. Ordering glutamic acid decarboxylase (GAD65) antibodies, islet cell (ICA2) antibodies and C-peptide levels can help differentiate between type 1 and type 2 diabetes. If GAD65 and ICA2 antibodies are negative and C-peptide levels are normal, the diagnosis is type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM). On the other hand, if GAD65 or ICA2 antibodies are positive and C-peptide levels are low, T1DM is the most likely diagnosis.  

Option Analysis

✅ Order C-peptide and GAD65 antibody levels:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Start insulin replacement therapy:
Incorrect: Initiation of insulin therapy is the definitive treatment for T1DM. Although this patient’s young age and family history of autoimmune disease could indicate T1DM, the diagnosis should be confirmed by measuring C-peptide and GAD65 antibody levels prior to treatment, especially considering his elevated BMI may indicate T2DM.  
❌ Start metformin therapy:
Incorrect: Metformin is the first-line treatment for T2DM. Although this patient’s BMI of 31 kg/m2 raises the suspicion of T2DM, other features point to T1DM. C-peptide and GAD65 antibody levels should be measured prior to treatment, to help determine if he has T1DM or T2DM.  
❌ Order HbA1C levels:
Incorrect: In a symptomatic patient with classic symptoms of hyperglycemia, the diagnosis of diabetes can be established if the patient has a random glucose level ≥ 200 mg/dL. This patient is symptomatic with a random blood glucose level of 260 mg/dL, therefore a HbA1c level is not required at this point for diagnosis or the initiation of treatment.  
❌ Refer for nutrition and exercise counseling:
Incorrect: Although nutrition and exercise consultations should be considered for all patients with diabetes, confirming the type of diabetes is required to guide management.

This patient with a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus presents with findings consistent with hyperosmolar hyperglycemic state (HHS), including blood glucose >600 mg/dL, elevated serum osmolality, evidence of profound dehydration, and the absence of metabolic acidosis and ketonuria. This patient’s potassium level is low, and given that she will continue to receive intravenous insulin, prompt administration of potassium is necessary. Insulin shifts potassium into cells; therefore with continued insulin infusion, potassium will decrease further, possibly precipitating arrhythmias.

Once HHS is diagnosed, management involves administration of intravenous normal saline and insulin. Patients should have their chemistry panel followed, and potassium repletion should be given if the serum potassium is <5.3 mEq/L while insulin is being given. In addition, patients should have corrected sodium levels calculated and have normal saline switched to 0.45% normal saline if the sodium level is normal or elevated. Blood glucose should be checked hourly, and insulin should be titrated to maintain a gradual decrease in serum levels. Once the blood glucose level falls to 250 to 300 mg/dL (13.9 to 16.7 mmol/L), the IV saline solution can be switched to dextrose in saline, and the insulin infusion rate can be decreased.

Option Analysis

✅ Administer supplemental potassium:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ No change in current management:
Incorrect: This patient has evidence of hypokalemia, and continued administration of insulin without potassium repletion could precipitate dangerous arrhythmias.  
❌ Continue normal saline:
Incorrect: Administration of 0.45% saline (half-normal saline) is indicated in patients with hyperosmolar hyperglycemic state (HHS) after initial fluid resuscitation if the patient’s corrected sodium levels are within or above the reference range. This patient's corrected sodium level is 141, so normal saline should be switched to 0.45% saline.  
❌ Bolus intravenous insulin:
Incorrect: This patient has had an adequate decrease in blood sugar following insulin infusion. An additional bolus of intravenous insulin is not required and, in fact, may worsen their current hypokalemia by possibly precipitating dangerous arrhythmias.  
❌ Switch to subcutaneous insulin:
Incorrect: This patient's blood sugar following initial therapy is still >300 mg/dL; therefore, she should continue to receive intravenous insulin infusion.

questions.text:
A 47-year-old man comes to the office because of intermittent abdominal pain and vomiting for the past two weeks. He was diagnosed with type II diabetes mellitus six months ago and was advised of lifestyle modifications initially. Metformin was initiated a month ago due to inadequate glycemic control. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and hypertensive nephrosclerosis. He takes carvedilol regularly. He does not smoke tobacco, consume alcohol, or use recreational drugs. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 95/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 105/60 mmHg. Laboratory findings are shown below. Considering metformin to be the most likely cause of this patient’s gastrointestinal upset, the physician changes metformin with a drug that binds to and inhibits ATP-sensitive potassium channels in the pancreatic beta cells. Which of the following is an example of this drug that can be safely administered to this patient? 

 Laboratory value     Result    
 Serum chemistry    
 Fasting blood glucose     140 mg/dL    
 Hemoglobin A1c     7.2%    
 Serum creatinine      2.3 mg/dL    
 Serum sodium      135 mEq/L    
 Serum potassium     5.5 mEq/L    
 Serum bicarbonate     18 mEq/L    
 Serum chloride     92 mEq/L
questions.solution:
Metformin is usually the first-line medication used to manage glucose in patients with type II diabetes mellitus. However, it is replaced by a sulfonylurea (glipizide) in this patient due to its intolerable side effects.        

Sulfonylureas are insulin secretagogues that act by inhibiting the K-ATP channel in the pancreatic beta cells. This causes the potassium channel to close, leading to the depolarization of pancreatic beta cells, followed by the influx of calcium (via voltage-gated calcium channels) and the subsequent insulin release in the blood at all glucose levels.        

There are two classes of sulfonylureas, as shown in the table below. Sulfonylureas are usually indicated for glycemic control in patients with suboptimal response, contraindications or intolerance to metformin, patients with severe hyperglycemia (fasting plasma glucose >250 mg/dL) or those with maturity-onset diabetes of the young.   



Option Analysis

❌ Chlorpropamide :
Incorrect: Although chlorpropamide works by inhibiting K-ATP channels in the pancreatic beta cells, it has a long duration of action (>48 hours) and is renally excreted. Therefore, this drug should be avoided in patients with compromised renal function (serum creatinine >2.3 mg/dL) to prevent drug-induced hypoglycemia. 
✅ Glipizide :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Exenatide :
Incorrect: Exenatide is a synthetic glucagon-like peptide, one analog that binds GLP-1 receptors and stimulates glucose-dependent insulin release from the pancreatic islets. It does not directly inhibit the K-ATP channel on pancreatic beta cells. 
❌ Sitagliptin :
Incorrect: Sitagliptin is a dipeptidyl peptidase 4 [DPP-4] inhibitor (an enzyme that deactivates glucagon-like peptide 1). Its inhibition results in the same effect as that of GLP-1 analogs, i.e. increased glucose-induced insulin release. It does not directly inhibit the K-ATP channel on pancreatic beta cells. 
❌ Canagliflozin :
Incorrect: Canagliflozin is a sodium-glucose co-transporter 2 (SGLT2) inhibitor that acts on the renal tubule to prevent the reabsorption glucose. Its efficacy is reduced in patients with chronic kidney disease and should be used cautiously. It does not affect insulin production by pancreatic beta cells.

questions.text: A 55-year-old postmenopausal woman comes to the office for a routine follow-up. She has no active complaints except for intermittent abdominal pain. Past medical history includes type 2 diabetes mellitus, chronic kidney disease, and inflammatory bowel disease. Her bone mineral density was -2.0 at her previous visit three months ago. Current medications include glyburide, acetaminophen, azathioprine, calcium, and vitamin D supplements. Family history is significant for bladder cancer in the patient’s father. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination is unremarkable. Her baseline serum creatinine is 2.5 mg/dL (eGFR 21 mL/min/1.73 m2) and recent HbA1c is 7.2%. The patient requests the physician to prescribe her pioglitazone, which has caused significant improvement in her neighbor’s blood glucose levels. Which of the following is a potential contraindication for initiating this medication?
questions.solution:
This patient with uncontrolled type 2 diabetes mellitus requests therapy with pioglitazone, a thiazolidinedione. Pioglitazone is known to increase the risk of fractures and is contraindicated in patients with low bone mineral density (2.0, indicative of osteopenia).        

Thiazolidinediones, also known as glitazones (e.g., rosiglitazone and pioglitazone), bind to peroxisome proliferator-activated receptors (PPAR)-ɣ in adipose tissue, pancreatic beta cells, and vascular endothelium and regulates the transcription of many insulin-responsive genes. The net effect is increased insulin sensitivity in peripheral tissues and reduced blood glucose levels.        

Glitazones also increase the synthesis of proteins involved in lipid metabolism, with a resultant decrease in triglycerides and an increase in both high-density lipoprotein and low-density lipoprotein. They are generally used as a second or third-line therapy in patients with type II diabetes mellitus. Still, They can be used as initial therapy when first-line agents are contraindicated.        

Contraindications to glitazone use include:      

  •  Heart failure or fluid overload  
 
  •  History of fracture or at high risk for fracture (e.g. postmenopausal woman with low bone density)  
 
  •  Liver disease  
 
  •  History of bladder cancer  
 
  •  Type 1 diabetes  
 
  •  Pregnancy  
Side effects include osteopenia, increased risk of fractures, hepatitis (or transaminitis), edema, weight gain, bladder cancer (pioglitazone), myocardial infarction (rosiglitazone), and heart failure.  


Option Analysis

✅ High risk of fracture :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Impaired renal function :
Incorrect: Impaired renal function (estimated glomerular filtration rate [eGFR] <30 mL/min/1.73 m2) is a contraindication to metformin use, as it increases the risk of lactic acidosis. Pioglitazone can be administered to patients with chronic kidney disease. 
❌ Inflammatory bowel disease :
Incorrect: Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is a contraindication to using an alpha-glucosidase inhibitor (e.g. acarbose). Pioglitazone is a thiazolidinedione and is not contraindicated in patients with IBD. 
❌ Type 2 diabetes mellitus :
Incorrect: Type 1 diabetes mellitus, not type 2, is a contraindication to pioglitazone use since it is efficacious only in patients with DM 2. 
❌ Family history of bladder cancer :
Incorrect: Pioglitazone is known to increase the risk of bladder cancer and is contraindicated in patients with active bladder cancer. However, a family history of this disease is not a contraindication to its use.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to the office for a routine follow-up. He has no active complaints, except for intermittent pain in his lower extremities. Past medical history is significant for type I diabetes mellitus and hypertension. He smokes one pack of cigarettes daily and does not drink alcohol or use illicit drugs. Vital signs are within normal limits. His home glucose readings demonstrate a constant elevation in postprandial blood glucose levels. HbA1c is 9.1%. Current medications include insulin lispro and lisinopril. The physician decides to add a new injectable medication that controls postprandial hyperglycemia by decreasing gastric emptying, suppressing glucagon release, and promoting satiety. Which of the following is an example of this medication?
questions.solution:
Pramlintide is an amylin analog administered subcutaneously during mealtime and regulates post-meal glucose by decreasing gastric emptying, suppressing glucagon release, and promoting satiety. Unlike other hypoglycemic medications, pramlintide can be used in type I and II diabetes. It is indicated in individuals taking prandial insulin (e.g, insulin, lispro) and must be injected immediately before a meal, at a site separate from that of insulin injection. Nausea is the most common side effect. Hypoglycemia can also occur, but only in the presence of other factors (e.g. mismatched timings with prandial insulin). It should be avoided in patients with gastroparesis history, as it delays gastric emptying. 

Option Analysis

❌ Metformin :
Incorrect: Metformin inhibits mitochondrial glycerophosphate dehydrogenase (mGPD), leading to the inhibition of gluconeogenesis by blocking pyruvate carboxylase, the first step of gluconeogenesis. This medication is administered orally and does not affect gastric emptying or glucagon release. 
❌ Canagliflozin :
Incorrect: Canagliflozin is a sodium-glucose co-transporter two inhibitor that acts on the renal tubule to prevent glucose reabsorption. It is an oral medication that does not affect gastric motility or glucagon release.  
❌ Pioglitazone :
Incorrect: Pioglitazone is a thiazolidinedione that binds to peroxisome proliferator-activated receptors (PPAR)-ɣ and increases insulin sensitivity of adipose tissue and muscle. It is contraindicated in patients with type 1 diabetes, as it is only active in the presence of insulin. 
❌ Glyburide :
Incorrect: Glyburide is an insulin secretagogue (sulfonylurea) that inhibits the K-ATP channel of pancreatic beta cells, which results in insulin release in the blood at all glucose levels.  
✅ Pramlintide :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 32 year old woman presents to the office for evaluation of frequent urination and increased thirst for 6 months without associated dysuria or hematuria. She has had vaginal itching with increased thick, white vaginal discharge without odor. She has used over the counter treatments 2 times in the past 3 months to treat possible yeast infections, but the discharge and itching returns. She has no known medical history and does not have a primary care provider. Family history is significant for diabetes mellitus in her mother and older sister, as well as hypothyroidism in her sister. Temperature is 36.9°C (98.5°F), pulse is 82/minute, blood pressure is 140/82 mmHg, BMI is 30. Skin examination reveals multiple skin tags on her neck and axilla and darkened, velvety skin on her neck. Cardiac and pulmonary examinations are unremarkable. On genitourinary examination, she has vulvar erythema and edema, with white, thick discharge. Wet mount of the vaginal discharge confirms the presence of candida.
